THE DEVALUATION OF COMPULSION

In almost every competitive area, including most of the world’s multitril ion-

dol ar investment activity, the migration of transactions into cyberspace wil

be driven by an almost hydraulic pressure—the impetus to avoid predatory

taxation, including the tax that in ation places upon everyone who holds his

wealth in a national currency.

Escaping the Protection Racket

You do not need to think long about the megapolitics of the Information Age

to realize that predatory taxes and in ation of the kind imposed as a matter of

right by the wealthiest industrial countries upon their citizens wil be

preposterously uncompetitive on the new frontier of cyberspace. Soon after

the turn of the mil ennium, anyone who pays income taxes at rates currently

imposed wil be doing so out of choice. As Frederic C. Lane pointed out,

history shows that on “the frontiers and on the high seas, where no one had

an enduring monopoly in the use of violence, merchants avoided payment of

exactions which were so high that protection could be obtained more cheaply

by other means. ”11

The cybereconomy provides just such an alternative. No government wil

be able to monopolize it. And the information technologies comprised by it

wil provide cheaper and more e ective protection for nancial assets than

most governments ever had reason to provide.

The Black Magic of Compound Interest

Remember, each $5,000 of annual tax payments paid over forty years slashes

your net worth by $2.2 mil ion, assuming you could realize just a 10 percent

return on your capital. At a 20 percent return, the compound loss bal oons to

about $44 mil ion. For high-income earners in a high-tax country, the

cumulative losses from predatory taxation over a lifetime are staggering. Most

wil lose more than they ever had.

This sounds impossible, but the mathematics are clear. It is something

that you can con rm for yourself with a pocket calculator. The top 1 percent

239

of taxpayers in the United States pay an average of more than $125,000 in

federal income taxes annual y. For a fraction of that amount, $45,000 a year,

one would be welcome to live under a private tax treaty in Switzerland, and

enjoy law and order provided by what is arguably the most honest police and

judicial system in the world. From this perspective, the additional $80,000 a

year of income tax paid above that generous level might wel be classi ed as

tribute or plunder. Forty- ve thousand dol ars is certainly a substantial

payment toward the maintenance of law and order, considering that police

protection is meant to be a public good. In theory, public goods can be

extended to additional users at a marginal cost of zero. The Swiss are glad to

have you pay a negotiated xed tax of $45,000 (50,000 Swiss francs) per year

because they make an annual pro t of $45,000 on every mil ionaire who signs

up.Compared to the Swiss alternative, the lifetime losses from paying federal

income tax at U.S. rates would be $705 mil ion for an investor who could

average a 20 percent rate of return. But remember, that assumes an annual tax

payment of $45,000. Compared to a tax haven like Bermuda, where the

income tax is zero, the lifetime loss for paying taxes at American rates would

be about $1.1 bil ion.

You may object that an annual return of 20 percent is a high rate of return.

No doubt you would be right. But given the startling growth in Asia in recent

decades, many investors in the world have achieved that and better. The

compound rate of return in Hong Kong real estate since 1950 has been more

than 20 percent per annum. Even some economies that are less widely known

for growth have a orded easy opportunities for high pro ts. You could have

pocketed an average real return of more than 30 percent annual y in U.S.

dol ar deposits in Paraguayan banks over the last three decades. High

investment returns are easier to realize in some places than others, but skil ed

investors can certainly achieve pro ts of 20 percent or more in good years,

even if they do not consistently match the performances of George Soros or

Warren Bu et.

Obviously, the higher the rate of return that you could earn on your

capital, the greater the opportunity costs that predatory income and capital

gains taxes impose. But the conclusion that the loss is huge, indeed greater

than the total amount of wealth that you may ever accumulate, does not

240

depend upon your being able to achieve outlandish rates of return. Some

mutual funds operating in the United States have averaged annual gains of

more than 10 percent for more than half a century. If you could do no better

than that and you are among the top 1 percent of American earners, then

your net worth is reduced by more than $33 mil ion just by the income tax

you pay in excess of $45,000 annual y. Compared to a jurisdiction without

income tax, the loss is $55 mil ion.

$55 Rather Than $55 Million

If the pro t-maximizing assumptions of economists are correct, as we believe

they general y are, one of the more certain predictions you could make is that

most people would act to salvage $55 mil ion if they could. That is our

prediction. When the black magic of compound interest becomes more clear

in the minds of successful people in high-tax countries, they wil begin to

shop in earnest among jurisdictions, just as they now shop for automobiles or

compare rates on insurance policies. If you doubt it, merely stop people at

random on the streets of New York or Toronto and ask whether they would

move to Bermuda for $55 mil ion. The question answers itself. The quandary

it poses is reminiscent of that Mark Twain imagined in deciding whether he

would prefer to spend the night with Lil ian Russel stark naked or General

Grant in ful dress uniform. He did not deliberate long. Residents of mature

welfare states, particularly the United States, may be slower on the uptake,

but only because they are not yet aware of the choice they face. In the ful ness

of time, they wil be. You or anyone motivated by the desire to live a better life

wil see the attraction of reducing the losses you su er from predatory

taxation. You need merely lodge your transactions in cyberspace. This wil , of

course, be il egal in many jurisdictions. But old laws seldom can resist new

technology. In the 1980s, it was il egal in the United States to send a fax

message. The U.S. Post O ce considered faxes to be rst-class mail, over

which the U.S. Post O ce claimed an ancient monopoly. An edict to that

e ect was issued reiterating the requirement that al fax transmissions be

routed to the nearest post o ce for delivery with regular mail. Bil ions of fax

messages later, it is unclear whether anyone ever complied with that law. If so,

compliance was eeting. The advantages of operating in the emerging

241

cybereconomy are even more compel ing than sidestepping the post o ce in

sending a fax.

Widespread adoption of public-key/private-key encryption technologies

wil soon al ow many economic activities to be completed anywhere you

please. As James Bennet, technology editor of Strategic Investment, has

written:

Enforcement of laws and particularly tax codes has become heavily dependent

on surveil ance of communications and transactions. Once the next logical

steps have been taken, and o shore banking locations o er the services of

communication in hard RSA-encrypted electronic mail using account

numbers derived from public-key systems, nancial transactions wil be almost

impossible to monitor at the bank or in communications. Even if the tax

authorities were to plant a mole in the o shore bank, or burglarize the bank

records, they would not be able to identify depositors.12

To a degree that has never before been possible, individuals wil be able to

determine where to domicile their economic activities and how much income

tax they prefer to pay. Many transactions in the Information Age wil not

need to be domiciled in any territorial sovereignty at al . Those that do wil

increasingly nd their way to places like Bermuda, the Cayman Islands,

Uruguay, or similar jurisdictions that do not impose income taxes or other

costly transaction burdens on commerce.

From Monopoly to Competition

Governments have become accustomed to imposing “protection services”

that are, in Frederic C. Lane’s words, “of poor quality and outrageously

overpriced. ”13 This habit of charging far more than government’s services are

actual y worth developed through centuries of monopoly. Taxes were

ruthlessly raised on anyone who seemed capable of paying—precisely because

governments had a monopoly or near-monopoly on coercion. This tradition

of monopoly wil clash in a profound way with the new megapolitical

possibilities of cybercommerce.

Encryption wil make it easy to protect transactions in cyberspace. The

cost of an e ective encryption software program, like PGP, is less than the

commission charged by a ful -service broker on a trade of one hundred shares.

242

Yet it wil render almost any transaction invisible and impervious to

governments and thieves for many years to come. The new technology of the

Information Age wil e ectively protect cyberassets at a vanishingly smal

cost. For $55 rather than $55 mil ion, participants in the cybereconomy wil

enjoy better actual protection of their assets than they enjoyed during the

industrial era or at any previous time in history. Easily used encryption

algorithms and the capacity to shop between terrestrial domiciles for

transactions wil provide e ective protection against the largest source of

predation, nation-states themselves.

That is not to say that territorial governments wil be entirely

outmaneuvered. They wil stil be able to exploit vulnerabilities to personal

harm in order to extract head taxes, or perhaps even hold wealthy individuals

to outright ransom. They wil also be able to enforce col ection of

consumption taxes. Yet protection, the most important service governments

provide, wil be put on a more nearly competitive basis. Less of the cost that

productive people pay for protection wil be available to be seized and

real ocated by political authorities. Technological innovations wil place a

large and growing portion of the world’s wealth outside the reach of

governments. This wil reduce the risks of trade, sharply lowering, in

historian Janet Abu-Lughod’s words, “the proportion of al costs” that

otherwise would have had to be “al ocated to transit duties, tribute, or simple

extortion. ”14

It has been rare in history to nd governments truly constrained by

competition. In the few times when something remotely like this has

happened, governments were weak and technologies were similar between

jurisdictions. As Lane suggested, the principal factor a ecting pro tability

under such conditions tends to be the di erence in protection costs paid by

di erent entrepreneurs. The medieval merchant who had to pay twenty tol s

to bring his goods to market could not compete with a merchant who had to

pay only four tol s to deliver the same goods to the customer. Similar

conditions are destined to return with the Information Age. Pro tability wil

once again be determined not so much by technological advantage as by your

success in minimizing the costs you are forced to pay for protection.

This new economic dynamic directly contradicts the desire of government

left over from the industrial era to impose monopoly pricing for its

243

protection services. But, like it or not, the old system wil be nonviable in the

new competitive environment of the Information Age. Any government that

insists upon lumbering its citizens with heavy taxes that competitors do not

pay wil merely assure that pro ts and wealth gravitate someplace else.

Therefore, the failure of the mature welfare states to curtail taxes over the

long term wil be self-correcting. Governments that tax too much wil simply

make residence anywhere within their power a bankrupting liability.

"… as the king by his prerogative may make money of what matter and form he

pleaseth, and establish the standard of it, so may he change his money in

substance and impression, and enhance or debase the value of it, or entirely decry

and annul it,…” 15

—FROM AN ENGLISH COURT DECISION, 1604

THE DEATH OF SEIGNIORAGE

Governments wil not only lose their power to tax many forms of income and

capital; they are also destined to lose their power of compulsion over money.

In the past, megapolitical transitions have been associated with changes in the

character of money.

The introduction of coinage helped launch the ve-hundred-year cycle of

expansion in the ancient economy that culminated with the birth of

Christ and the lowest interest rates before the modern period.

The advent of the Dark Ages coincided with virtual closure of the mints.

While Roman coinage continued to circulate, quantities of money

dwindled along with trade in a self-reinforcing downward spiral.

The feudal revolution coincided with a reintroduction of money, coinage,

bil s of exchange, and other devices for settling commercial transactions.

In particular, a surge in European silver production from new mines at

Rammelsberg, Germany, facilitated an increase in the circulation of coin

that helped lubricate commerce.

The greatest revolution in money prior to the Information Age came with

the advent of industrialism. The early-modern state consolidated its power

in the Gunpowder Revolution. As its control increased, the state asserted

its power over money, and came to rely heavily upon the signature

244

technology of industrialism, the printing press. The rst implement of

mass production, the printing press, has been widely used by governments

in the modern period to mass-produce paper money.

Paper money is a distinctly industrial product. It would have been

impractical before the printing press to duplicate receipts or certi cates that

became paper currency. Certainly, monks in the scriptoria would not have

spent their time wel drawing fty-pound notes. Paper money also

contributed signi cantly to the power of the state, not only by generating

pro ts from depreciating the currency, but by giving the state leverage over

who could accumulate wealth. As Abu-Lughod put it, “when paper money

backed by the state become the approved currency, the chances for amassing

capital in opposition to or independent of the state machinery became

di cult.” 16

CYBERCASH

Now the advent of the Information Age implies another revolution in the

character of money. As cybercommerce begins, it wil lead inevitably to

cybermoney. This new form of money wil reset the odds, reducing the

capacity of the world’s nation-states to determine who becomes a Sovereign

Individual. A crucial part of this change wil come about because of the e ect

of information technology in liberating the holders of wealth from

expropriation through in ation. Soon, you wil pay for almost any

transaction over the Net or World Wide Web at the same time you place it,

using cybercash.

This new digital form of money is destined to play a pivotal role in

cybercommerce. It wil consist of encrypted sequences of multihundred-digit

prime numbers. Unique, anonymous, and veri able, this money wil

accommodate the largest transactions. It wil also be divisible into the tiniest

fraction of value. It wil be tradable at a keystroke in a multitril ion-dol ar

wholesale market without borders.

Dialing Without Dollars

245

Inevitably, this new cybermoney wil be denationalized. When Sovereign

Individuals can deal across borders in a realm with no physical reality, they

wil no longer need to tolerate the long-rehearsed practice of governments

degrading the value of their money through in ation. Why should they?

Control over money wil migrate from the hal s of power to the global

marketplace. Any individual or rm with access to cyberspace wil be able to

easily shift out of any currency that appears in danger of depreciation. Unlike

today, there wil be no necessity to deal in legal tender. Indeed, in transactions

spanning the globe it wil be likely that at least one party to every transaction

wil nd himself dealing in a currency that is not legal tender to him.

Disadvantages of Barter Reduced

You wil be able to trade in any medium you wish in the cybereconomy. As

the late Nobel Prize-winning economist F. A. Hayek argued, there is “no clear

distinction between money and non-money.” He wrote, “although we

usual y assume there is a sharp line of distinction between what is money and

what is not—and the law general y tries to make such a distinction—so far as

the causal e ects of monetary events are concerned, there is no such clear

di erence. What we nd is rather a continuum in which objects of various

degrees of liquidity, or with values which can uctuate independently of each

other, shade into each other in the degree to which they function as

money.” 17 Digital money on global computer networks wil make every

object on Hayek’s continuum of liquidity more liquid—except government

paper. One consequence wil be that barter wil become far more practical.

Increasing numbers of objects and services wil be o ered in speci c bids for

other objects and services. These potential transactions wil be widely

advertised throughout the world on the Net, which wil increase their

liquidity by magnitudes.

One of the principal drawbacks of barter has always been the di culty of

matching a person with one speci c demand with another who had exactly

that on o er and was seeking to acquire for himself exactly what the rst

proposed to trade. Primitive barter stumbled over the daunting improbability

of exactly matching two parties wishing to exchange in a local market. Cash

transcended the limitations of barter, and its advantages wil continue to be

246

compel ing in most transactions. But vast increases in computational power

and the globalization of commerce in cyberspace also reduce the drawbacks of

barter. The odds of nding someone with exactly reciprocal desires to yours

increase dramatical y when you can sort instantly across the entire world

rather than drawing on only those whom you might meet local y.

Not Subject to Counterfeiting

While paper money wil no doubt remain in circulation as a residual medium

of exchange for the poor and computer-il iterate, money for high-value

transactions wil be privatized. Cybermoney wil no longer be denominated

only in national units like the paper money of the industrial period. It

probably wil be de ned in terms of grams or ounces of gold, as nely

divisible as gold itself. Or it may be de ned in terms of other real stores of

value. Even where di erent pricing measures are used, or certain transactions

continue to be denominated in national currencies, cybermoney wil serve

the consumers far better than nationalized money ever did. Rapidly

advancing computational capacity wil diminish the di culties of adjusting

prices to various media of exchange to the vanishing point. Each transaction

wil involve the transfer of encrypted multihundred-digit prime-number

sequences. Unlike the paper-money receipts issued by governments during

the gold-standard era, which could be duplicated at wil , the new digital gold

standard or its barter equivalents wil be almost impossible to counterfeit for

the fundamental mathematical reason that it is al but impossible to unravel

the product of multihundred-digit prime numbers. Al receipts wil be

veri ably unique.

The names of traditional currencies like the “pound” and the “peso”

re ect the fact that they originated as measures of weight of speci c

quantities of precious metals. The pound sterling was once upon a time a

pound of sterling silver. Paper money in the West began as warehouse or safe-

deposit receipts for quantities of precious metals. Governments issuing these

receipts soon found that they could print far more of them than they could

actual y redeem from their supply of bul ion. This was easy. No individual

holding a gold or silver certi cate could distinguish any information about

the actual supply of precious metals from his receipt. Other than the serial

247

numbers, al the receipts looked alike, a fact that appealed to counterfeiters as

wel as politicians and bankers seeking to pro t from in ating the supply of

money.

Cybermoney wil be al but impossible to counterfeit in this way, o cial y

or uno cial y. The veri ability of the digital receipts rules out this classic

expedient for expropriating wealth through in ation. The new digital money

of the Information Age wil return control over the medium of exchange to

the owners of wealth, who wish to preserve it, rather than to nation-states

that wish to spirit it away.

The Transaction Cost of “Free” Currency

Use of this new cybermoney wil substantial y free you from the power of the

state. Earlier, we cited the dreary record of the world’s nation-states in

maintaining the value of their currencies over the past half century. No

currency has su ered a smal er loss from in ation since World War II than the

German mark. Yet even so, 71 percent of its value vanished between January

1, 1949, and the end of June 1995. The world reserve currency during this

period, the U.S. dol ar, lost 84 percent of its value.18 This is a measure of the wealth that governments expropriated by exploiting their territorial

monopolies on legal tender.

Note that there is no intrinsic necessity that currency depreciate or that

the nominal cost of living rise every year. To the contrary. The technical

chal enge of maintaining the purchasing power of savings is trivial. You can

see this merely by looking at the long-term purchasing power of gold.

Between January 1, 1949, and the end of June 1995, while the best of

nationalized currencies lost almost three-quarters of its value, the purchasing

power of gold actual y rose. As documented by Professor Roy W. Jastrom in

his book The Golden Constant, gold has maintained its purchasing power,

with minor uctuations, for as far back as reliable price records are available,

to 1560 in the case of England.

National currencies linked to gold have also maintained their purchasing

power when military exigencies were not pressing. The value of the British

pound sterling rose, rather than fel , during the relatively peaceful nineteenth

century even though it was only weakly linked to gold. The new mega-

248

political conditions of the Information Age make feasible not a weak link, like

the gold standard, but a strong link, reinforced for the rst time by vastly

improved information and computational resources in the hands of

consumers.

The threat of the speedy loss of their whole business if they failed to meet

expectations (and how any government organization would be certain to abuse the

opportunity to play with raw material prices!) would provide a much stronger

safeguard than any that could be devised against a government monopoly. 19

—FRIEDRICH A. VON HAYEK

Privatizing Money

Friedrich von Hayek argued in 1976 that the use of competitive, private

currencies would eradicate in ation.20 Without legal-tender requirements

forcing acceptance of an in ating currency within a jurisdiction, Hayek

argued, market competition would force the private issuers of currency to

preserve the value of their exchange media. Any issuer of a private currency

failing to maintain its value would soon lose its customers. The evolution of

encrypted cybercash wil bring Hayek’s logic vividly to life.

The theory of “free banking,” as it is cal ed, is not merely a hypothetical

academic speculation. Private competing currencies circulated in Scotland

from early in the eighteenth century until 1844. During that period, Scotland

had no central bank. There were few regulations or restrictions on entry into

the banking business. Private banks took deposits and issued their own

private currencies backed by gold bul ion. As Professor Lawrence White has

documented, this system worked wel . It was more stable, with less in ation

than the more heavily regulated and politicized system of banking and money

employed in England during the same period.21 Michael Prowse of the

Financial Times summarized Scotland’s free-banking experience: “There was

little fraud. There was no evidence of over-issue of notes. Banks did not

typical y hold either excessive or inadequate reserves. Bank runs were rare and

not contagious. The free banks commanded the respect of citizens and

provided a sound foundation for economic growth that outpaced that in

England for most of the period.” 22

249

What worked wel under the technological conditions of the eighteenth

and nineteenth centuries wil work even better with twenty- rst-century

technology. You wil soon be able to deal in digital money from a private rm,

issued much as American Express issues traveler’s checks as receipts for cash.

An institution of greater repute than any government, such as a leading

mining company or the Swiss Bank Corporation, could create encrypted

receipts for quantities of gold or even for unique bars, identi ed by molecular

signatures and possibly even inscribed with holograms. These receipts wil

then trade as money, with almost no possibility that they can be counterfeited

or in ated.

The new digital gold wil overcome many of the practical problems that

inhibited direct use of gold as money in the past. It wil no longer be

inconvenient, cumbersome, or dangerous to deal in large sums of gold.

Digital receipts wil not be too heavy to carry. Indeed, their only physical

existence wil be as elaborate patterns of computer code. Nor wil it be

di cult to divide digital receipts into units smal enough to pay for even

microvalue purchases. A wafer of physical gold tiny enough to pay for a

chiclet would soon be lost or confused with one tiny enough to pay for two

chiclets. But it wil be as easy for the computer to distinguish these

demoninations of digital money as if they were the size of a chipmunk and a

rhinoceros.

The capacity of digital money to deliver micropayments wil facilitate the

emergence of new types of businesses that heretofore could not have existed,

specializing in organizing the distribution of low-value information. The

vendors of this information wil now be compensated through direct-debit

royalty schemes that overcome previously daunting transaction costs. When

the cost of bil ing exceeds the value of a transaction, it probably wil not take

place. Use of cybermoney facilitates very-low-cost simultaneous bil ing, in

which accounts are debited with use. We cited such an example above in

imagining that you might pay a royalty equivalent to one-third of a penny to

Bil Gates, or whoever owns the virtual-reality rights to tour the Louvre.

Multiply this in a thousand ways. Virtual reality wil create almost unlimited

licensing opportunities that wil nevertheless command only microroyalty

payments. One day you wil be able to replay the third game of the 1969

250

World Series, and pay microroyalties to the players whose images are used to

make your virtual reality seem real.

ERADICATING INFLATION

Such possibilities notwithstanding, surely the most momentous consequence

of the new digital money wil be the end of in ation and the deleverage of the

nancial system. The economic implications are profound. The rise of

in ation in the twentieth century, as we argued in Blood in the Streets and The

Great Reckoning, was intimately connected with the balance of power in the

world. Increasing returns to violence dictated sharply higher military

expenditures, which in turn required ever more aggressive e orts to

expropriate wealth. Governments found that they could e ectively impose an

annual wealth tax on al who held balances in their national currencies. This

annual wealth tax on currency holders could also be seen as a transaction fee

for al owing the users of currency to maintain their wealth in a convenient

form provided by the issuers.I

Thinking of in ation as a transaction fee for the convenience of holding

currency may be unusual, but consider it closely. During the Industrial Age

we became so accustomed to thinking of the provision of currency as a service

for which one does not pay directly, that it was easy to forget that the issuers

of the dol ars, pesos, pounds, and francs, namely governments, did require

that we pay, and pay dearly—through in ation. The rate of this in ationary

transaction fee on currency varied during the last half century from a low of

2.7 percent annual y for the German mark, to rates perilously close to 100

percent. For example, between 1960 and 1991, when President Menem

launched Argentina’s currency-board reform, in ation struck seventeen zeros

o successive versions of Argentine currency. If al the wealth of the world

had been converted into Argentine pesos in 1960 and buried, it would not

have been worth the e ort to spade it up by 1991.

Argentina’s example is a leading indicator for the next mil ennium.

Currency wil not be in ated because other nation-states wil no longer be

able to get away with it just as Argentina no longer can. The di erence wil be

that private money dispersed over the Net wil be even less susceptible to a

reversal in policy than Argentina’s automatic currency-board system, which

251

could be damaged by a credit contraction imported from other countries.

Private money wil not be in atable because of competitive market pressures.

The death of in ation wil take away the disguised pro ts that in ation

previously conveyed to those who were the monopolistic issuers of currency.

If al the disguised pro ts of issuing money were extinguished, a new method

of payment would be needed to compensate the issuers of currency directly.

Use of the new monetary system wil therefore probably involve a more

explicit transaction cost, perhaps a fee on the order of 1 percent per annum.

This wil be a smal price to pay compared to the annual in ationary penalty

of from 2.7 percent to 99 percent imposed by nation-states. Al the more so,

because there is a likelihood that overal prices wil decline in the future as

monopolies are eroded and competition intensi es worldwide.

Contracting Leverage

The emergence of digital money wil not only defeat in ation once and for

al ; it wil also contract leverage in the banking systems of the world. The

ability of people everywhere to bypass regulatory authorities and shift their

funds directly through the Internet is an entirely unprecedented consequence

of the globalization of markets. It wil be beyond the power of any

government to regulate. When governments can no longer depreciate

currency by printing money or defraud savers by expanding credit at wil

through captive banking systems, they wil lose a major part of their indirect

capacity to commandeer resources.

Higher Interest Rates

This wil create an obvious dilemma for most Western governments. They

wil face sharp drops in revenue from taxation and the virtual elimination of

leverage in the monetary system. At the same time, they wil retain the

unfunded liabilities and in ated expectations for social spending inherited

from the industrial era. The result to be expected is an intense scal crisis

with many unpleasant social side e ects that we wil consider in later

chapters. The economic consequence of this transition crisis wil probably

include a one-time spike in real interest rates. Debtors wil be squeezed as

252

long-term liabilities contracted under the old system are liquidated, and

concessionary credits dry up.

Altered by Competition

Governments facing serious competition to their currency monopolies wil

probably seek to underprice the for-fee cybercurrencies by tightening credits

and o ering savers higher real yields on cash balances in national currencies.

Some governments may even seek to remonetize gold as another expedient to

meet competition from private currencies. They may wel reason that they

could gain higher seigniorage pro ts from a loosely control ed nineteenth-

century gold standard than would be the case if they al owed their national

currency to be displaced entirely by commercial cybermoney. But not al

governments wil respond in the same way. Those in regions where computer

usage and Net participation are low may opt for old-fashioned hyperin ation

in the early stages of the cybereconomy. This wil not enable these

governments to capture the cash balances of the rich, but it wil wring

resources from those with little wealth or access to the cybereconomy.

Governments using such tactics might nonetheless borrow international y in

cybermoney.

Stil other governments may adapt to the opportunities created by the

information economy, and facilitate local transactions in cybermoney. Those

jurisdictions that rst recognize the validity of digital signatures and provide

local court enforcement of repossession for nonpayment of cyberdebts wil

stand to bene t from a disproportionate surge in long-term capital lending.

Obviously, no cybermoney would be available for long-term credits in

territories where local courts imposed penalties or permitted debtors to

default without recourse.

Yield Gap

The combination of credit crises, competitive adjustments by national

monetary authorities, and early transitional obstacles to lending

cybercurrency wil lead to a yield gap in the early stages of the information

economy. Cybermoney wil pay lower interest rates than national currencies

253

and wil probably also carry explicit transaction costs. O setting these

apparent drawbacks to holding balances in digital money wil be enhanced

protection against losses due to predatory taxes and in ation. Because it wil

probably be gold-linked, cybermoney wil also bene t from the appreciation

of gold. The price of gold wil probably rise signi cantly relative to other

commodities, no matter which of the alternative government policies

predominates.

Why?

The real price of gold almost always rises in de ation. A de ation, after al ,

re ects a shortage of liquidity. Gold is the ultimate form of liquidity.

The Deflation of the Industrial Age

Higher real rates al around wil spur liquidation of high-cost, unproductive

activities, and temporarily reduce consumption. We explored the logic of the

credit cycle and its unwinding in Blood in the Streets and The Great

Reckoning, so we wil not rehearse those arguments here. Su ce it to say that

the de ationary environment may drag on for some time, with more adverse

consequences in the high-cost industrial economies of North America and

Western Europe than in the low-cost economies in Asia and Latin America.

Lower Rates Long-Term

While the early consequences of the emergence of the cybereconomy are

likely to include higher interest rates, the longer-term consequence wil be

just the opposite. The after-tax returns to savers wil sharply increase as

resources escape the grasp of governments. Dramatic improvements in the

e ciency of resource use, and the liberation of capital to nd the highest

returns global y, should rapidly compensate for the output lost early in the

transition crisis.

Investor Control over Capital

Conventional thinkers reviewing our argument at this point would conclude

that the breakdown of income redistribution in the leading nation-states

254

would doom the world to economic col apse. Do not believe it. We do not

gainsay the fact that a transition crisis would be likely. But the view that the

state improves the functioning of the economy by massive real ocation of

resources is an anachronism, an article of faith roughly equivalent to the

widespread superstitions at the close of the Middle Ages that fasting and

agel ation were bene cial for a community. It should not be forgotten that

governments waste resources on a large scale. Wasting resources makes you

poor. A dramatic improvement in the e ciency of resource use wil arise

when revenues historical y engrossed by governments come to be control ed

instead by persons of genuine talent.

Tens of bil ions, then ultimately hundreds of bil ions of dol ars wil be

control ed by hundreds of thousands, then mil ions of Sovereign Individuals.

These new stewards of the world’s wealth are likely to prove far abler than

politicians in utilizing resources and deploying investment. For the rst time

in history, megapolitical conditions wil al ow the ablest investors and

entrepreneurs rather than specialists in violence ultimate control over capital.

It is not unreasonable to expect that the rates of return on this dispersed,

market-driven investment could be double or triple the meager returns from

the political y driven budget al ocations of the nation-state era. It was not

uncommon in the nal decades of the twentieth century to nd examples in

any country of government investment that were substantial y negative. We

cited o cial Russian statistics in the revised version of The Great Reckoning

from November 1992, suggesting that the whole of Russia’s economy was

“worth just $30 bil ion, less than a third of the value of its raw-material

inputs. By implication, the output of Russia’s economy would more than

triple in value if the domestic manufacturing and service economy were shut

down completely. Instead of contributing value, they subtract it. ”23

Admittedly, the example of Russia after the col apse of Communism is an

extreme one, but there is ample evidence that reducing state control of

resources tends to improve economic e ciency. Growth rates cited by the

Economist suggest that economic liberty is strongly correlated with economic

growth, with the most rapid rates of growth in the freest countries. The

cybereconomy of the Information Age wil be more free than any other

commercial realm in history. It is therefore reasonable to expect that the

cybereconomy wil rapidly become the most important new economy of the

255

new mil ennium. Its success wil attract new participants from everywhere on

the globe, in the same way that the wide use of fax machines made

telecopying increasingly attractive for nonusers. But even more important,

freedom from predatory violence wil al ow the cybereconomy to grow at far

higher compound rates of growth than conventional economies dominated

by nation-states.

That is perhaps the most important point to be made in anticipating the

economic impact of the likely col apse of monopoly taxing and in ating

capacities of government. Setting aside transition di culties, which could last

for decades, the long-term prospects for the global economy should be highly

bul ish. Whenever circumstances al ow people to reduce protection costs and

minimize tribute paid to those who control organized violence, the economy

usual y grows dramatical y. As Lane said, “I would like to suggest that the

most weighty single factor in most periods of growth, if any one factor has

been most important, has been a reduction in the proportion of resources

devoted to war and police.” 24

There could be great e ciency gains arising from a reduction of the

resources devoted to predation and living o the spoils of predation. If the

pricing of protection were placed on a competitive basis, with local

monopolies competing for customers on a basis of price and quality,

potential y huge gains to e ciency would be possible. The result to be

expected would be much lower rates of taxation and less loss of resources and

e ort in political activity, which would no longer pay its previously huge

dividends.

Would voters wil ingly forgo political windfal s to which they have

become accustomed? That is an issue we take up at length elsewhere. But a

simple answer is that we may have no choice. No one now demonstrates

against rainy weather, or draught, however economical y damaging or

unpleasant it may be. No one, however criminal y inclined, holds a pauper to

ransom demanding a huge payment on pain of death. If it becomes

impossible for politicians to obtain resources to redistribute, the public may

respond in a rational way and forget about politics, just as wel -intentioned

people ceased organizing marches of penitents when the Middle Ages came to

an end.

I. In ation had another lure during the industrial period when prices and wages were downwardly in exible. Modest in ation increased output by reducing real wages and prices.

CHAPTER 8

THE END OF EGALITARIAN ECONOMICS

The Revolution in Earnings Capacity in a

World Without Jobs

“God is not mocked: for whatsoever a man soweth, that shall he also reap.”

—GALATIANS 6:7

Great changes in the dominant forms of production or defense change the

structure of society, and the proportion of wealth and power of di erent

groups. The Information Age means more than just a growing use of

powerful computers. It means a revolution in lifestyles, institutions, and the

distribution of resources. Because the role of covert violence in control ing

resources wil be sharply diminished, a new con guration of wealth wil

develop, without the coercive mediation by government that characterized

the twentieth century. Because location wil mean much less in the

Information Society, there wil be a diminished role in the future for al

organizations that operate within rather than beyond geographic boundaries.

Politicians, labor unions, regulated professions, lobbyists, and governments

per se wil be less important. Because favors and restraints of trade wrested

from governments wil be less valuable, fewer resources wil be wasted either

to promote or resist lobbying.

Those who have employed compulsion and local advantage to redistribute

income are destined to lose much of their power. This wil alter the command

of resources. Privately generated wealth that heretofore has been

commandeered by the nation-state wil be retained instead by those who earn

it. Increasing amounts of wealth wil nd their way into the hands of the

258

ablest entrepreneurs and venture capitalists worldwide. Globalization, along

with other characteristics of the information economy, wil tend to increase

the income earned by the most talented individuals in each eld. Because the

marginal value generated by superlative performance wil be so huge, the

distribution of earnings capacity throughout the entire global economy wil

take much the shape it does now in the performance professions like athletics

and opera.

A MAGNITUDE BEYOND PARETO’S LAW

Pareto’s law says that 80 percent of the bene t wil depend on or go to 20

percent of those engaged. This may be approximately true, though, more

strikingly, 1 percent of the population of the United States pays 28.7 percent

of the income tax, suggesting that as societies advance into the Information

Age they wil experience an even more skewed distribution of incomes and

abilities than Vilfredo Pareto observed at the end of the last century. People

are quite accustomed to substantial inequalities of wealth. In 1828, 4 percent

of New Yorkers were thought to have owned 62 percent of al the city’s

wealth. By 1845, the top 4 percent owned about 81 percent of al corporate

and noncorporate wealth in New York City. More broadly, the top 10

percent of the population owned about 40 percent of the wealth across the

whole United States in 1860. By 1890, records suggest that the richest 12

percent then owned about 86 percent of America’s wealth.1

The 1890 numbers are close to what Pareto had in mind. They vary from

his ratio of 80-20 percent mainly because a huge in ux of penniless

immigrants arrived in America at the end of the nineteenth century. The

immigrants’ share of total wealth was negligible; therefore, their arrival

automatical y made the total holdings of wealth more unequal. In fact, this is

a striking il ustration of the fact that any genuine upsurge in opportunity is

almost inevitably bound to lead to at least a brief surge in inequality. By 1890,

immigrants accounted for about 15 percent of the total U.S. population, but

more than 40 percent in some of the northeastern states, where much of the

income and wealth were generated. 2 Adjusting for the surge in immigration,

late-nineteenth-century America t Pareto’s formula about as wel as late-

nineteenth-century Switzerland, where he lived.

259

The Information Age has already changed the distribution of wealth,

particularly in the United States, and is one of the reasons for the bitterness of

modern American politics, which we explore further in the next chapter. The

Information Age requires a quite high standard of literacy and numeracy for

economic success. A massive U.S. Education Department survey, “Adult

Literacy in America,” has shown that as many as 90 mil ion Americans over

the age of fteen are woeful y incompetent. Or in the more colorful

characterization of American expatriate Bil Bryson, “They are as stupid as

pig dribble. ”3 Speci cal y, 90 mil ion American adults were judged incapable

of writing a letter, fathoming a bus schedule, or adding and subtracting, even

with the help of a calculator. Those who cannot make sense of an ordinary

bus timetable are unlikely to be able to make much of the Information

Superhighway. From this third of Americans who have not prepared

themselves to join the electronic information world, an angry underclass is

being recruited. At the top of society is a smal group, perhaps 5 percent, of

highly educated information workers or capital owners who are the

Information Age equivalent of the landed aristocracy of the feudal age—with

the crucial di erence that the elite of the Information Age are specialists in

production, not specialists in violence.

The Megapolitics of Innovation

For no very good reason, most twentieth-century sociologists have assumed

that technological progress would natural y tend to produce increasingly

egalitarian societies. This was not true prior to about 1750. Beginning around

that time, innovative new industrial technology began to open job

opportunities for the unskil ed and increase the scale of enterprise. The new

technology of the factory not only raised the real earnings of the poor

without any e ort on their part; it also tended to increase the power of

political systems, making them more able to redistribute income as wel as

more capable of withstanding unrest. Taking a longer view, there is no

inherent reason to suppose that technology always tends to mask rather than

accentuate the di erences in human talents and motivation. Some

technologies have been relatively egalitarian, requiring contributions of many

independent workers of approximately equal utility; others have put power

260

or wealth into the hands of a few masters while most people were little more

than serfs. Both history and technology have shaped di erent nations in

di erent ways. The Factory Age produced one shape, and the Information

Age is producing another, less violent, and therefore more elitist and less

egalitarian than the one it is replacing.

AMMON’S TURNIP

In the late nineteenth century a number of economists, of whom Wil iam

Stanley Jevons was the most distinguished in England, started to develop

mathematical economics. One of the rst to apply probability theory to a

major social question was the German economist Otto Ammon, whose work

was rst translated into English by Carlos C. Closson in an article in the

Journal of Political Economy in 1899. The article was entitled “Some Social

Applications of the Doctrine of Probability. ”4 One might suppose that such

an article was now of purely antiquarian interest. In fact, it deals with an

economic problem that is again coming to the fore, and deals with it in what

is stil a stimulating way.

Otto Ammon was interested in the distribution of ability in society, and

its relationship to the distribution of income and status. He took as his

starting point the probable occurrence of total scores from four dice, each

with six sides. Out of 1,296 possible throws, some totals wil occur much

more often than others.

The sum of

It is immediately apparent that high and low scores are both comparatively

rare. There are two possible totals, but the top four of these only occur thirty-

ve times out of the 1,296, and the bottom four only occur thirty- ve times.

The middle seven group of scores can be expected to occur 884 times; the

middle third of possible scores is the result in more than two-thirds of al

throws. This produces the characteristic crowding toward the center of

probability theory.

Otto Ammon argued that this random distribution of throws of the dice

was matched by the distribution of human abilities. He was writing before

the development of intel igence testing and IQs, and relied on the earlier

work on intel igence of Francis Galton. Ammon did not consider that social

utility, or success in life, depended simply on intel igence. He listed “three

groups of mental traits which are largely decisive in the place which a man

wil occupy in life.” These were:

1. Intellectual traits; among which I included al that belong to the rational side

of man-power of quick comprehension, memory, power, of judgement, power

of invention, and whatever also belongs to this eld.

2. Moral traits; namely, self control, wil power, industry, perseverance,

moderation, regard for family obligations, honesty and the like.

3. Economic traits; such as business ability, organizing talent, technical skil ,

caution, clever calculation, foresight, thrift and so on.

To these mental traits he added:

4. Bodily traits; power to work, endurance, power of undergoing exertions and

of resisting excitements of every kind, vigour, good, health, etc.

262

In Otto Ammon’s view, the probable distribution of these qualities of

intel igence, character, talent, and body were similar to those of scores on the

dice. He went further and argued that there were, in fact, many more than

four variables, and that they varied in more than six degrees. If instead of

throwing four dice, one throws eight, then there are no less than 1,679,616

possible throws, yet the highest score, forty-eight, can stil only be expected to

occur once. The man or woman who scores very highly in al the factors that

determine the place in life is much rarer than the probability of throwing four

sixes would suggest; perhaps as rare as throwing eight sixes. Yet, Ammon

notes, a mixture of high and low scores in these human qualities may produce

“persons of unbalanced, inharmonious gifts, who, in spite of some bril iant

qualities, cannot successful y meet the tests of life.”

“Like a lonely mountain peak, or rather, like the spire of a cathedral, rise the men

of high talent and of genius above the broad mass of mediocrity.… The number of

the highly gifted is at all events so small that it is impossible that ‘many’ such can

have been kept back in lower classes through the incompleteness of social

institutions.”

—OTTO AMMON

Traits and Incomes

Ammon then turns to the distribution of incomes. Of course, the statistics of

the 1890s were much less adequate than they would be now, but German

bureaucracy was already wel developed, and Otto Ammon found in Saxony,

Prussia, Baden, and other German states income curves that he thought were

similar, both to his perceived distribution of human ability and to the

probabilities of the dice. He found similar gures in Charles Booth’s Life and

Labour of the People of London (1892). Indeed, Booth’s social distribution

does look much as one might expect from Ammon’s probability theory.

Booth found in London 25 percent who were poor or worse, 51.5 percent

who were comfortable, and 15 percent who were wel -to-do, or better; if one

takes the two lowest of Booth’s categories they come to 9.5 percent. It was

common before the welfare states of the twentieth century to speak of those

who were least wel o as the “submerged tenth. ”5 The two highest of Booth’s categories come to 7 percent.

263

From al this, Otto Ammon drew a number of interesting conclusions. He

thought that people’s abilities, broadly de ned, determined their place in

society and their income. He believed that high abilities natural y result in

people rising in income and social position. “Like a lonely mountain peak, or

rather, like the spire of a cathedral, rise the men of high talent and of genius

above the broad mass of mediocrity,…” He also believed that the “true form

of the so-cal ed social pyramid is that of a somewhat at onion or turnip.”

This turnip has a narrow stem above and a narrow root beneath. Such a social

turnip is preferable as a metaphor to the social pyramid because, like modern

industrial society, it has its mass in the middle while the pyramid has its mass

at the bottom.

The Shape of the Turnip

Modern industrial societies are indeed al turnips, with a smal wealthy and

upper-professional class at the top, a larger middle class, and a minority poor

class at the bottom. Relative to the middle, both the extremes are smal . In

modern London, if not in Washington, there are certainly more mil ionaires

than homeless.

Al of this is intriguing, but the immediate interest of Ammon’s work lies

in the major long-term shift we are experiencing in the relations, nancial and

political, between the top and the middle. The skil s needed in the Factory

Age, which is now passing, are undeniably di erent from those demanded by

the Information Age. Most people could master the skil s required for

operating the machines of the mid-twentieth century, but those jobs have

now been replaced by smart machines which, in e ect, control themselves. A

whole arena of low- and middle-skil employment has already disappeared. If

we are correct, this is a prelude to the disappearance of most employment and

the recon guration of work in the spot market.

“Yet it is a fact, acknowledged officially but quietly, that most of the unemployed

youngsters have no qualifications whatsoever…”6

—CLIVE JENKINS AND BARRIE SHERMAN

FEWER PEOPLE WILL DO MORE WORK

264

We can take the simple four-dice distribution of human ability and suppose

that people could score in the Factory Age with a set of 4 X 2 or above. That

would mean that over 95 percent of the population were above what Charles

Booth cal ed “the lowest limit of positive social usefulness.” Indeed, 3 percent

was set as the ful -employment standard of the 1940s and 1950s. Suppose

that in the Information Age the required score has risen to a 4 X 3, and the

required minimum has gone up from 8 to 12. That would mean that nearly

24 percent would fal below this limit of “social usefulness.”

Something similiar would happen at the top end of the scale. In the

Factory Age, the required level of high ability was perhaps 4 X 4; suppose that

in the Information Age it has risen to 4 X 5. In that case the proportion of

people quali ed for the top jobs, which are also the best paid, would fal from

34 percent to 5 percent.

These numbers are purely hypothetical. Obviously, we do not know what

the shift in the skil requirements wil be—or has already been—but there has

certainly been a rise. Because of the shape of the turnip, a quite modest rise in

the minimum skil requirement would put large numbers outside of a

signi cant economic role. Equal y, quite a smal rise in the higher skil

requirement would reduce the number of people quali ed for the higher jobs

very dramatical y. Some shift is happening: we do not yet know how big it

wil be.

There is indeed no lack of social and political evidence that this shift is

taking place in al advanced industrial societies, that its pace is accelerating,

and that the movement is already a big one. The rewards for rare skil s have

increased and are increasing. This has been noted with displeasure by

conventional thinkers. Consider, for example, The Winner-Take-All Society,

by Robert H. Frank and Philip J. Cook.7 It documents the growing tendency

for the most talented competitors in many elds in the United States to earn

very high incomes. Equal y, the opportunities for middle skil s are fal ing; a

substantial, number of low skil s now fal outside the range that is rewarded

with a comfortable living, though they may stil nd a place in smal -scale

services.

If the Information Age demands higher skil s both at the top and bottom

end, everyone except for the top 5 percent wil be relatively at a disadvantage,

but the top 5 percent wil gain tremendously. They wil both earn a higher

265

share of income and keep a greater share of what they earn. At the same time,

they wil do a greater portion of the world’s work than ever before. Many wil

emerge as Sovereign Individuals. In the Information Age, the turnip of

income distribution wil look more as it did in 1750 than in 1950.

Societies that have been indoctrinated to expect income equality and high

levels of consumption for persons of low or modest skil s wil face

demotivation and insecurity. As the economies of more countries more

deeply assimilate information technology, they wil see the emergence—so

evident already in North America—of a more or less unemployable

underclass. This is exactly what is happening. This wil lead to a reaction with

a nationalist, antitechnology bias, as we detail in the next chapter.

The Factory Age may prove to have been a unique period in which

semistupid machines left a highly pro table niche for unskil ed people. Now

that the machines can look after themselves, the Information Age is pouring

its gifts onto the top 5 percent of Otto Ammon’s turnip. The Information

Age was already looking far better for the top 10 percent, the so-cal ed

cognitive elite. Yet it wil be the best of al for the top 10 percent of the top 10

percent, the cognitive double top. In the feudal age, it took one hundred

semiskil ed peasants to support one highly skil ed warlord (or knight) on

horseback. The Sovereign Individuals of the information economy wil not

be warlords but masters of specialized skil s, including entrepreneurship and

investment. Yet the feudal hundred-to-one ratio seems set to return. For

better or worse, the societies of the twenty- rst century are likely to be more

unequal than those we have lived in during the twentieth.

MOST PEOPLE WILL GAIN FROM THE DEATH OF POLITICS

It is unlikely that the egalitarian economy and the nations it supports can

disappear without a crisis. While a “crisis” by de nition can last only for a

short while, we nonetheless imagine that the trauma of the end of nations

could reverberate for years. Without ignoring that trauma, whose dimensions

we explore in greater detail later, it is important not to forget that in many

areas of the globe the transition to the information economy wil lead output

to surge, with higher incomes al around. Indeed, in those areas that never

266

shared ful y in the bene ts of industrialism but are now open to the free market, incomes are rising or wil rise among al classes of people.

The de ation of compulsion as a feature of economic life wil al ow

producers to retain assets that heretofore have been seized and redistributed.

Redistribution usual y meant that assets were dragooned into lower-value

uses, thus reducing the productivity of capital. Wealth taken

disproportionately from persons who were most adept at investing resources

was real ocated by politicians to those who were less adept. In most cases,

redistributed income was employed in lower-order economic activities. The

e ects of freeing resources from systematic compulsion wil vary greatly

among jurisdictions. This freezing of resources wil bankrupt welfare states,

and enhance diseconomies to scale that are undermining large governments

and al institutions subsidized by large governments. On the other hand, the

shift to the cybereconomy wil reduce the economic drawbacks su ered by

people operating under sovereignties in regions that have traditional y

su ered from the inability to organize on a large scale.

“If the world operates as one big market, every employee will compete with every

person anywhere in the world who is capable of doing the same job. There are lots

of them and many of them are hungry.” 8

—ANDREW S. GROVE, PRESIDENT, INTEL CORP.

SHIFTING LOCATIONAL ADVANTAGES

Because there wil no longer be rising returns to violence, there wil be no

advantage to living under a government that could capture them. Once-

competent governments wil no longer be the friends of wealth

accumulation, but their enemies. High taxes, burdensome regulatory costs,

and ambitious commitments to income redistribution wil make territories

under their control uninviting settings in which to do business.

Those who live in jurisdictions that remained poor or underdeveloped

during the industrial period have the most to gain by the liberation of

economies from the con nes of geography. This is contrary to what you wil

hear. The main controversy surrounding the advent of the information

economy and the rise of the Sovereign Individual wil focus on the al egedly

267

adverse e ects on “fairness” arising from the death of politics. It is certainly

true that the advent of the global information economy wil deal a mortal

blow to large-scale income redistribution. The main bene ciaries of income

redistribution in the Industrial Age have been inhabitants of wealthy

jurisdictions whose level of consumption is twenty times higher than the

world average. Only within the OECD countries has income redistribution

had noticeable e ects in raising incomes of unskil ed persons.

The greatest income inequalities have been observed among jurisdictions.

Income redistribution has done little to al eviate them. In fact, we believe that

foreign aid and international development programs have had the perverse

e ect of lowering the real incomes of poor people in poor countries by

subsidizing incompetent governments. This is an issue we consider in more

depth in analyzing the impact of the Information Revolution on morality.

A Century of Rising Income Inequality

During the industrial period, the factor that contributed most to determining

the ordinary person’s lifetime income was the political jurisdiction in which

he happened to reside. Contrary to the common impression in rich

economies today, income inequality rose rapidly during the industrial period.

An estimate cited by the World Bank suggests that average per capita income

in the richest countries bal ooned from eleven times that in the poorest

countries in 1870 to fty-two times in 1985.9 While inequality increased dramatical y on a global basis, it often appeared otherwise to the fraction of

the world inhabiting the wealthy industrial countries. Income inequality rose

among jurisdictions rather than within them.

For reasons we have already explored, the character of industrial

technology itself helped assure that income gaps would narrow within

jurisdictions where halfway competent governments mastered the exercise of

power on a large scale. When returns to violence were rising, as they were

during the Industrial Age, governments that operated on a large scale tended

to be control ed by their employees. This made it e ectively impossible to

impose controls on the claims these governments made over resources. Their

unchecked control over resources conveyed an important military advantage

so long as magnitude of power predominated over the e ciency with which

268

it was used. A not-incidental corol ary of government control ed by its

employees was a sharp acceleration of income redistribution. Almost every

society has some provision for income redistribution, at least on a temporary

basis in extraordinary circumstances. However, a close reading of the history

of the provision of aid to the poor shows that “welfare” bene ts tend to be

more generous when poverty is minimal. Income redistribution is more likely

to be curtailed when incomes for large numbers weaken. Conditions in the

wealthy industrial societies in the last half of the twentieth century were

almost perfect for redistributing income. This led to much higher rewards for

unskil ed work within these favored jurisdictions. In due course, it even

provided high levels of consumption for those who did not work at al .

The Paradox of Industrial Wealth

The irony is that it was also in these jurisdictions that more people became

wealthy. This apparent paradox makes perfect sense once you understand the

dynamics of megapolitics explored in previous chapters. Leading sectors of

the industrial economy required the maintenance of order on a large scale to

function optimal y. This made them particularly vulnerable to extortion by

unions and governments eager to maximize the number of persons under

their sway. Yet widespread redistribution of income did not total y sti e the

ability of the industrial economy to function. Anyone lucky enough to be

born in Western Europe, the former British settlement colonies, or Japan

during the high-water period of industrialism was therefore likely to be far

richer than a person of equivalent skil s in South America, Eastern Europe,

the late Soviet Union, Africa, and the landmass of Asia. The bene cial impact

of information technology wil include helping to overcome many of the

obstacles to development that prevented the majority of the world’s

population from enjoying many of the bene ts of free markets during much

of the modern period.

“The indigenous characteristics of poor countries are strikingly inhospitable to

effective large-scale organization, especially to large-scale organizations that have

to operate (as governments do) over a large geographical area.” 10

—MANCUR OLSON

269

DISECONOMIES OF SCALE AND RETARDED GROWTH

As Mancur Olson has demonstrated, backwardness in the twentieth century

was not due to lack of capital or specialized skil s per se. In “Diseconomies of

Scale and Development,” an essay published in 1987, two years before the fal

of the Berlin Wal , Olson wrote, “If capital had in fact been in scarce supply

in the poor countries, its ‘marginal productivity’ and so the pro tability of its

use ought to be greater than in the prosperous countries. The low growth

rates of many countries that received nonnegligible amounts of foreign aid

and the low productivity of some modern factories that were built in poor

countries have further lessened the credibility of the ‘scarcity of capital’

explanation of underdevelopment. ”11 This must be right. Had capital or skil

scarcity been the main de ciency, the returns earned by both in poor

jurisdictions would have been higher than in developed countries. Both

skil ed personnel and capital would have ooded into these regions until the

returns leveled out. In fact, the opposite was often the case. There was a

substantial outmigration of educated people from backward jurisdictions.

And the lucky few who did manage to accumulate capital in such places

exported it as rapidly as possible to Switzerland and other advanced countries.

Better Government Could Not Be Imported

Olson argues, and we agree, that the true obstacle to development in

backward countries has been the one factor of production that could not be

easily borrowed or imported from abroad, namely government. This is a

problem that worsened as the twentieth century unfolded. In 1900, Great

Britain and France, along with some other European countries, were in the

business of exporting competent government to regions where indigenous

powers were incapable of functioning e ectively on a large scale. But shifting

megapolitical conditions in the twentieth century raised the costs and

lowered the returns for this activity. Colonialism, or imperialism, as it was less

fondly known, ceased to be a paying proposition. Shifts in technology raised

the costs of projecting power from the center to the periphery and lowered

the military costs of an e ective resistance. Consequently, imperial powers

270

withdrew, or stayed on only in tiny enclaves, like Bermuda or the Cayman

Islands.

“If the postcolonial nation-state had become a shackle on progress, as more and

more critics in Africa seemed to agree by the end of the 1980s, the prime reason

could appear in little doubt. The state was not liberating and protective of its

citizens, no matter what its propaganda claimed; on the contrary, its gross effect

was constricting and exploitative, or else, it simply failed to operate in any social

sense at all. ” 12

—BASIL DAVIDSON

The indigenous governments that replaced colonial rule in the countries

that were not settled by Europeans drew their leaders and administrators

from populations who had little experience or skil at running any type of

large-scale enterprise. In many cases, especial y in Africa, infrastructure

inherited from the departing colonial powers was rapidly looted, destroyed,

or al owed to fal into disrepair. Telephone lines were torn down by

scavengers and hammered into bracelets. Roads were no longer maintained.

Rail lines became useless as roadbeds fel apart and locomotives broke down.

In Zaire, the elaborate transportation infrastructure instal ed by the Belgians

had almost total y disappeared by 1990. Only a few creaky riverboats

continued to function, one of which was taken over as a kind of oating

palace by the dictator.

Undependable communication and transport re ect the incompetence of

backward nation-states at maintaining order. They have kept prices high and

minimized opportunities for most of the world’s population. As Olson

emphasizes:

First, poor transportation and communication tend to force a rm to rely

mainly on local factors of production. When a rm’s scale increases, it wil have

to go further a eld to obtain factors of production, and the poorer the

transportation and communications systems the faster these factor costs wil

rise with expanding output.

The second and more important reason why poor transportation and

communication systems work against e ective large-scale enterprises is that

they make it far more di cult to coordinate such enterprises e ectively.” 13

271

Lightening the Burden of Bad Government

The ambitious poor of the world, more than anyone, stand to bene t as

information technology disconnects the capacity to earn income from the

locale in which one lives. New technologies, such as the digital cel ular

telephone, al ow communications to function independently of the ability of

the local police to defend every telephone pole in a jurisdiction from copper

thieves. As wireless fax and Internet connections become available, it no

longer matters so much whether desperately poor postal employees wil pilfer

mail just to steal the stamp.

In many cases, e ective communications are even replacing the need for

the physical transport of goods and services. Better communications and

vastly increased computational power not only make coordination of

complex activities cheaper and more e ective; they also lower scale economies

and dissolve large organizations. These changes al tend to reduce the penalty

that persons in backward countries have su ered for living under

incompetent governments. The Information Revolution wil make it much

less important whether governments are able to function capably. It wil

therefore be easier for persons living in traditional y poor countries to

surmount the hurdles that their governments have heretofore placed in the

path of economic growth.

Equal Opportunity in the Information Age

In the Information Age, familiar locational advantages wil rapidly be

transformed by technology. Earnings capacity for persons of similar skil s wil

become much more equal, no matter in what jurisdiction they live. This has

already begun to happen. Because institutions that have employed

compulsion and local advantage to redistribute income are losing power,

income inequality within jurisdictions wil rise. Global competition wil also

tend to increase the income earned by the most talented individuals in each

eld, wherever they live, much as it does now in professional athletics. The

marginal value generated by superior performance in a global market wil be

huge.

While public debate wil focus on growing “inequality” in the OECD

countries, individuals everywhere wil enjoy far more nearly equal

272

opportunity. They wil no longer need to live in a jurisdiction that functions

wel on a large scale in order to succeed. Innate abilities and the wil ingness to

develop them wil be measured on a more equal playing eld than ever before.

Jurisdictional advantages that led to widening inequality between rich and

poor economies during the industrial period wil change dramatical y.

Higher Returns in Poor Areas

The obstacles that governments in poorer regions place in the way of

functioning free markets wil be much diminished as the cybereconomy

comes on line. As a consequence, capital and skil s in short supply wil in fact

earn higher returns in many currently poor areas, much as the development

theorists of the 1950s postulated they should. And both capital and skil s wil

be far more readily importable. Emerging economies wil no longer need to

rely as much as during the Industrial Age upon local factors of production.

Their enhanced ability to draw upon capital and expertise at a distance wil

lead to higher rates of growth. This wil happen whether or not incompetent

governments become more honest or better able to protect property rights.

Lacking power over cyberspace, bad governments wil simply be less able to

stop people in their jurisdictions from bene ting from economic freedom.

Positive Reinforcement

In the new cybereconomy, the almost total portability of information

technology wil prohibit the hoarding of many of the jurisdictional

advantages that arose in the Industrial Age. Enhanced competition between

increasing numbers of jurisdictions wil turn on new types of local advantage.

Sovereignty wil be commercialized rather than predatory. Governments wil

be obliged by the force of competition to set policies to appeal to those of

their customers who make the greatest contributions to economic wel -being,

not to those who contribute little or whose economic contributions are

negative.

This wil represent a tremendous change from the common practice of the

twentieth century. The ideology of the nation-state was that life can and

should be regulated in a positive way by subsidizing undesirable outcomes

273

and penalizing desirable ones. To be poor is undesirable; therefore, the poor

were subsidized. To become rich is desirable; therefore, punitive taxes were

laid on the rich to make life more “fair.”

Because this whole policy approach was rooted in a megapolitical

foundation that withstood al appeal, it mattered little what the perverse

consequences of subsidizing dysfunction were. Nor was there much

accounting for the skil , hard work, or ingenuity that went into earning the

wealth that was redistributed. Outcomes were measured in terms of

entitlements. The twentieth-century political view assumed that in order for

outcomes to be “fair” they had to be equal.

The New Paradigm

The new megapolitical conditions of the twenty- rst century wil al ow

market tests to regulate outcomes in areas formerly dominated by politics.

The market paradigm presupposes that results can be better regulated by

rewarding desirable outcomes and penalizing undesirable ones. To be poor is

undesirable, and to become rich is desirable. Therefore, incentives should

reward wealth creation and encourage people to pay for the resources they

consume. Life is more “fair” when people get to keep more of what they earn.

This is a view that wil be heard more frequently in the new mil ennium

than it was in the century now ending. Furthermore, it wil be compel ing as

never before because it wil be megapolitical y founded. Capital in the

Information Age is growing more mobile by the moment. The capacity to

earn high income is no longer tied to residence in speci c locations, as was the

case when most wealth was created by manipulating natural resources. With

every day that passes, it becomes easier for people using highly portable

information technology to create assets that are far less subject to the leverage

of violence than any form of wealth has ever been before.

Arbitrary political regulations that impose costs without creating

o setting market bene ts wil soon be nonviable. Powerful competitive forces

are tending to equalize the prices of goods, services, labor, and capital across

the globe. Governments wil have less latitude to impose arbitrary policies

than they are accustomed to enjoy. Any government that attempts to impose

more burdensome regulations on an activity than other sovereignties wil

274

simply drive that activity away. In some cases, of course, driving away

unwanted activities wil please the market and make those jurisdictions al the

more popular and prosperous. In this sense, certain regulations may be

compared to the house rules imposed by the proprietors of a hotel chain. If

they prohibit people from walking barefoot or smoking in the lobby, they wil

no doubt lose certain customers. But turning away those customers may not

cost the jurisdiction customers overal , or even reduce its total revenues. Wel -

shod nonsmokers may pay more precisely because barefoot smokers are

excluded. Equal y, regulations that make it costly or impossible to operate a

rendering plant in a certain jurisdiction may drive the rendering elsewhere

without depriving the jurisdiction as a whole of income.

These examples demonstrate how regulations may in rare circumstances

have a positive rather than a negative market value, especial y in a world with

a rapidly multiplying number of jurisdictions. Rules that preserve high

standards of public health, clean air, and clean water wil be highly valued in

many locales. So wil other, sometimes more exotic regulations and covenants

of the kind that might be imposed by real estate developers or hotels catering

to certain market segments.

No Customs House in Cyberspace

We expect the commercialization of sovereignty to rapidly lead to the

devolution of many large territorial sovereignties. The very fact that

information technology cannot be subjected to border controls of the kind

that can stil impede the trade of manufactures and farm goods has important

implications. It means that protectionism wil be less e ective over time as

trade in information displaces physical products in the generation of wealth.

It also means that smal er regions wil be ever less dependent upon the

maintenance of extensive political jurisdictions in order to assure access to

markets in which they can earn income.

Information technology exposes people working in formerly protected

service sectors to foreign competition. If a rm in Toronto wished to hire a

bookkeeper twenty years ago, that person had to be physical y located in

Toronto, or in a nearby community within commuting distance. In the

Information Age, a bookkeeper in Budapest or Bangalore, India, could do the

275

job, and download al the material needed in encrypted form over the

Internet. Instant communication through satel ite links makes any part of the
